active_learning.discussion_prompt: MD2 was designed for efficient digital signatures in the early 1990s but is now obsolete due to vulnerabilities like practical collision attacks. Debate the trade-offs between efficiency and security in hash functions, comparing MD2 to modern alternatives like SHA-256. What lessons from MD2's deprecation can inform future algorithm design and crypto hygiene?

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in cryptography. Generate high-quality Anki-compatible flashcards for 'MD2 Algorithm Specifications' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 001_Cryptography > Hash Functions > 003_Hash Function Algorithms and Standards > MD Family Algorithms > MD2 Algorithm Specifications). Use the provided learning_objectives (span Bloom's: remember to create), active_learning components (embed discussion/problem hooks), scaffolding layers (cover all 4 progressively), and flashcard_schema (mix types, follow distractor_protocol). Context: MD2 (RFC 1319, obsoleted RFC 6149) produces 128-bit digest for digital signatures. Padding: to 16-byte multiples + length mod 256. State: 48 bytes (X,C,M). Per block: 3 passes. 18 mixing rounds with S-box. Vulns: collisions (2004). Alternatives: SHA-256. Prerequisites: hash properties, signatures. Output ONLY a JSON array of flashcards, each as: {"type": "basic/cloze/multiple_choice", "front": "...", "back": "Answer\nExplanation: ... (Bloom: LEVEL, Layer: #, Source: RFC1319)", "tags": ["MD2", "hash", "cybersec"]}. Balance: 40-60 cards, 25% MC. Ensure active recall, no hints in front. Voter priorities: pedagogy (objectives, discussion), completeness (vulns, best practices), problem-solving.
